unnormalised: So, someone asked me about when Holi is celebrated, and it got me thinking… growing up in Bihar, Holi wasn't just a day, it was an experience. It all starts with Holika Dahan, right? Usually the night before Holi, which this yr falls on 25/03/2024. We’d gather around this massive bonfire, chanting prayers and throwing coconuts and other stuff into the fire. My grandma always said it was to burn away all the negativity.
normalised: So, someone asked me about when Holi is celebrated, and it got me thinking… growing up in Bihar, Holi wasn't just a day, it was an experience. It all starts with Holika Dahan, right? Usually the night before Holi, which this year falls on twenty fifth March two thousand and twenty four. We’d gather around this massive bonfire, chanting prayers and throwing coconuts and other stuff into the fire. My grandma always said it was to burn away all the negativity.

unnormalised: Then comes the actual day of Holi, which is usually the day after Holika Dahan, which is, in this case, 26/03/2024. That's when the real fun starts. Colors everywhere! Gulal, abir, all sorts of crazy shades. The best part was running around with my cousins, chasing each other with pichkaris filled with colored water. We’d start pretty early, around 8:00 AM IST, and it would go on till, like, 4:00 PM IST. By the end of it, you’re completely unrecognizable.

unnormalised: One yr, I remember, we got into a huge water fight with the Sharma family. It was hilarious. Auntiji was chasing us with a bucket, and uncleji was trying to sneak up on us with a hose. We ended up soaking everyone, including the poor delivery guy who showed up at 10:30 AM with the sweets.

unnormalised: The thing about Holi is, it's not just about the colours. It's about coming together, forgetting all your differences, and just having a good time. Even now, living in Mumbai, I try to make it back home for Holi every year. It’s just not the same celebrating it anywhere else. This year, though, I might have to prepone my visit to 23/03/2024 since there's some office work to wrap up.

unnormalised: And of course, no Holi celebration is complete without the food. My mom makes the best gujiya and dahi bhalle. And then there's the thandai, spiked with a little bhang for the adults. Just enough to make everyone a little extra silly and cheerful. Usually, the festivities extend up to evening 7:00 PM, with families visiting each other and exchanging sweets.

unnormalised: Thinking back, Holi mornings starting around 9:00 AM felt like a scene from a Bollywood movie, only much more chaotic and real. The neighbours would blast music, usually old Hindi songs, and everyone would dance in the streets. Even the grumpy old uncle in our building would crack a smile and join in.

unnormalised: So, yeah, Holi is more than just a date on the calendar. It’s a feeling, a memory, a celebration of life, love, and togetherness. I’m already looking forward to celebrating it on 25th-26th March, 2024, with my family. Hopefully, this gives you a good idea of when and how we celebrate it!
